chapter.title: Configuring Your System
chapter.para: This chapter contains information on configuring your system.

sect1.title: Desktop Customisation
sect1.para: This section details some tips for customising the desktop. They are mostly tips for customising the desktop environment (called GNOME), and the file manager (called Nautilus).

sect2.title: Run programs automatically when GNOME starts

listitem.para:
Choose
System Preferences Sessions .
Click on the Startup Programs tab.
Use the Add, Edit, and Delete buttons to manage programs to run at startup.

sect2.title: Login automatically to GNOME when the computer starts
sect2.para: It is possible to login a user automatically when the computer boots. This is not recommended for most computers, as it is not secure and may allow other users access to your information

listitem.para: Select the General tab. Check the Login a user automatically on first bootup checkbox option.

sect2.title: Show hidden files and folders in Nautilus

listitem.para: In Nautilus, use the Ctrl H shortcut keys to toggle hidden files and folders on and off.
To permanently show all hidden files and folders, choose Edit Preferences .
Click on the Views tab.
Select the Show hidden and backup files check box.

sect2.title: Open the Location Bar in Nautilus
sect2.para:
The Location Bar is the bar in your file manager in which you can type an address. Toggle the bar on and off with:
Go Location...
You can also use the Ctrl L shortcut keys.

sect2.title: View remote SSH, FTP, and SFTP servers using Nautilus

listitem.para: Make sure the Nautilus Location Bar is open (see ).
In the Location Bar, enter the following:
For SSH, use: ssh://username@ssh.server.com
For FTP, use: ftp://username@ftp.server.com
For SFTP, use: sftp://username@sftp.server.com

Replace username with your username and replace everything after the @ symbol with the server's address. You will be prompted for a password if needed. If there is no username (anonymous) omit the username and the @ symbol.
Alternatively, to specify your password manually, change one of the above like so: ftp://username:password@ftp.server.com

sect2.title: Change the default file type "Open with" program

listitem.para:
In Nautilus, right click on the file and choose
Properties
from the menu that appears. The Properties dialog opens.
Click on the Open With tab. A list of applications appears.
Select the default application you want for the file type. If the application is not on the list, use the Add button to add the application to the list.

listitem.para: Make sure the Universe and Multiverse repositories are enabled. (See )

listitem.para:

System Preferences Preferred Applications .
Click on the Mail Reader tab, and select the Custom option.

In the Command text box, type

sect2.title: Digital Cameras
sect2.para: Most USB digital cameras will be automatcially detected by Ubuntu. Simply just plug in and switch on your USB digital camera, Ubuntu will then ask you if you would like to import the photos from your camera. Click on Import, Ubuntu will then show you a preview of your photos. Choose a location to save your photos to, then click on Import, Ubuntu will then save your photos to your hard drive.

sect3.title: Winmodems
sect3.para: Most winmodems are not supported by Ubuntu, but drivers can be found that will enable the use of such modems. First you need to identify what chipset your winmodem is using:

para.screen: wget -c &scanmodem-url; gunzip -c &scanmodem-gz; > scanModem chmod +x scanModem sudo ./scanModem gedit Modem/ModemData.txt

sect3.para: Check the output in Gedit, it should list what modem chipset you have. Once you are aware of the chipset you have, see &linmodem; and follow the directions for your modem. More infomation can be found at SettingUpModems on the Ubuntu Wiki.

sect3.title: ADSL Modems
sect3.para: All PPPOE and router-style ADSL modems are supported by Ubuntu (that use ethernet for the connections), and some USB ADSL modems are supported too. For router-style ADSL modems, just connect it up, configure the modem as per your ISPs instructions and configure networking in Ubuntu. For information on PPPOE modems see ADSLPPoE on the Ubuntu wiki.

sect2.title: Development Tools
sect2.para: This section has a list of handy open source development tools for use on Ubuntu such as Integrated Development Environments and powerful editors.

listitem.para: Anjuta is a versatile Integrated Development Environment (IDE) for C and C++ on GNU/Linux.
Bluefish is a powerful editor for experienced web designers and programmers.
Eclipse is an open source community whose projects are focused on providing a vendor-neutral open development platform and application frameworks for building software.
eric3 is a full featured Python (and Ruby) IDE that is written in PyQt using the QScintilla editor widget.
IDLE is the Python IDE built with the Tkinter GUI toolkit.
The KDevelop-Project aims to build up an easy to use IDE for KDE. KDevelop supports many programming languages.
MonoDevelop is a free GNOME IDE primarily designed for C# and other .NET languages.
NetBeans is an open-source project dedicated to providing rock solid software development products.
